Message.Title: Battle for Clearwire
Message.Msg: CLWR yahoo message board - interesting excerpt: " Sprint will be able to take Majority Control of the Board after McCaw deal closes By relevance2code.Oct 27, 2012 8:30 AM.Permalink "Additionally, Sprint and Eagle River recently disclosed that Eagle River plans to sell all of its shares of Clearwire stock to Sprint. If this transaction is completed, Sprint will no longer be required by the terms of the Equityholders' Agreement to appoint at least one independent director. Also, Sprint, either on its own, or at the direction of Softbank if their proposed transaction is successfully completed, may elect to change its designees on our board of directors." - 10Q p. 51 How did everyone miss this? Because of the cause and effect of: "seven directors will be nominated by Sprint (one of whom must qualify, for so long as there are not more than two independent designees, as an independent director...)" As a result of McCaw's board seat becoming independent, there are now 3 (more than two) independent designees. Therefor Sprint can designate a full 7 of 13 board seats. This will not give them complete control as 75% vote is still required for a merger and must be approved by Intel and Comcast. And 10 of 13 votes are required for certain actions. But it will give them the ability to claim majority control of the board if they choose to. Re: Sprint will be able to take Majority Control of the Board after McCaw deal closes By nivegulu.Oct 27, 2012 4:03 PM.Permalink If that is true then it's a lawsuit waiting to happen!. It means that we have been sold out (for a fraction of the intrinsic spectrum value) for 3 years with the "make whole" clause ostensibly covering the transaction. Also, any third party cannot buy out clear or their spectrum fair and square in an unskewed fashion (without facing uncalled for resistance). I think this invokes the "breach of fiduciary duty" laws towards clear's shareholders, and the respondents would be clear's board incuding McCaw. Re: Re: Sprint will be able to take Majority Control of the Board after McCaw deal closes By nivegulu.Oct 28, 2012 1:48 AM.Permalink Also, that may be the reason intel and comcast are'nt selling their shares for a song. They know that if they do so wittingly (knowing there will be a tilt in control of the company's ownership) it would amount to a breach of fiduciary duty and cheating of the public shareholders. Moreover, if they have not voiced their vote of dissent over the ERH deal at the board level, the only way they (intel for now) can now redeem and indemnify themselves is to purchase McCaws shares under the ROFB for the "right price" -that which reflects the true asset value of the company (i.e. clear)." Please see the complete discussion thread on the YMB for CLWR.

Topic.Title: W8 Reviews - What They Don't Say

Message.Msg: There are a lot of reasons Intel could go to $30 or beyond but it won't be because W8 gives anyone incentive to go buy a new a desktop or laptop without a touch screen. In fact, some buyers of new W8 PCs may choose to downgrade to W7 which Microsoft allows. Intel's shares have been held back because of its inability to participate in the mobile space. W8 (excluding RT) should help Intel in convertible ultrabook and tablet sales but forcing a tablet-smartphone paradigm on nearly a billion desktop/laptop Windows users is insane. Not everyone wants to have finger prints all over their high res display. What is humorous is that even when Microsoft tries to copy Apple they can't even do it right.

Topic.Title: INTC SHORT INTEREST 182,497,589

Message.Msg: short interest is growing

Topic.Title: W8 Reviews - What They Don't Say

Message.Msg: MS had previously tired to make operating systems for handheld devices that resembled its PC operating systems. And that didn't work. But now they are dancing around in glee because they figured out that the correct strategy is to make the PC operating system look like the mobile phone operating system. The problem, of course, is the lack of discipline, lack of confidence, propensity to panic, disregard for professional needs, and over-reaction to tablets such that they think a tablet operating system should be on all computers. They could just have a separate operating system for tablets. For instance, when sitting at a desktop the reach for the mouse is a shorter reach than for the screen. And so who would want to pay extra for a touch screen on a desktop ? Or who wants to have the large desktop screen so close to the face ? But Windows 7 is supported until the year 2020. So the PC makers might be making a mistake if they don't offer a choice of Win 7 or Win 8.

Message.Title: Windows8 --- 8 sec. to boot.
Message.Msg: "Windows 8 was built for touch, and it's meant to be touched. Nay, it begs to be touched. I checked out the standard version of Microsoft's latest operating system, which debuted Friday, on Dell's new XPS 12, a slick, powerful convertible that uses Intel's robust and road-tested Ivy Bridge architecture. Here's what I found. The XPS 12 and other convertibles give users the ability to easily switch back and forth between tablet and a clamshell/keyboard mode. Except for obvious applications like word processing, however, I didn't use the keyboard much. Windows 8's brightly colored Live Tiles invite touch and, despite some getting used to, I found it faster and more efficient to touch, tap and swipe my way around the system instead of clicking and clacking .. The first thing you'll notice about a Windows 8 tablet or PC is how fast it boots. The XPS 12, running a powerful Intel Core i7 chip and carrying 8 GB of RAM, was fully on about eight seconds after a cold boot. Shutting down was even faster--about three seconds. Microsoft and its hardware partners have clearly fulfilled their promise to deliver the sort of on/off experience that we've come to expect from consumer appliances. "

Topic.Title: Windows8 --- 8 sec. to boot.

Message.Msg: Just back from Best Buy. Checked out Windows 8 and the new ultra books. You can switch from Windows 8 to 7 and back again in a second. Half had touch screens and they had one convertible which just folded over to a tablet. Some people there were worried about switching to windows 8 but when I showed them how easy it was to switch back to 7 if they wanted to they were impressed.

Topic.Title: Windows8 --- 8 sec. to boot.

Message.Msg: If you put an SSD in a Windows XP machine, it boots in eight seconds. This is just the latest blob of bloatware from Redmond. Nobody there actually knows how the kernel works, so they just keep putting it on faster and faster hardware to hide the problem.

Topic.Title: Windows8 --- 8 sec. to boot.

Message.Msg: I have some doubts about an 8-second 64-bit XP w/ SP3 boot time. I don't know of anyone who has actually done it so I will have to take your word for it. I know that given a choice of Win7 or XP, it would be an easy choice for me. IMO, there are very few people who understand how any large program works. Whether is be Windows (any flavor), Linux (any flavor including UNIX variants like Apple uses), large applications (SAP, Oracle, X, HPC apps ...) or any large program, there are few if any who understand the inner workings of them. As for bloatware, can you point to any software that has not grown larger and more complex as the CPU power and memory space available has increased? I cannot think of any programs that got smaller and removed features they supported.

Topic.Title: Windows8 --- 8 sec. to boot.

I'm at least short term long (if that makes any sense - 3 to 6 months)... however I think someone that was looking for popping in an out of the stock, they could be doing well shorting around 22 and buying around 21.50... of course, I'm really hoping that next week it makes progress in the up direction as good and better than it did this week... Lovely would be $24 or $25 by the end of next week, but that seems like an impossibility at this point... unless some real radically good news comes across the chain... Of course if the shorts get their wishes, we'll see $20 to $21 by the end of next week...

Message.Title: OMG, the 8 second boot time becomes the new In-Dell mantra
Message.Msg: Does it not occur to you that the machine reviewed was specially prepped? Short boot time has been the "Lost Ark," for In-Dell and Microsoft since 1995 or thereabouts. It has never happened, mostly because of the industry's own specs. For instance, it is, "required," to wait 60 seconds for a SCSI device to respond. Thirty seconds for ATA/IDE/SATA devices. And on and on and on. I mean, M'God, if you install Windows Vista, it still looks for Ultra-IO, Adaptec and other ancient devices. "Please Press F3 To Install A Third Party Keyboard Driver."

Topic.Title: OMG, the 8 second boot time becomes the new In-Dell mantra

Message.Msg: Why don't you just upgrade your 10.1 inch Atom Netbook VISTA machine and quit complaining!!! DELL's 8-second claim is 15% slower than others are seeing. 7-seconds is the target boot time. NOT SPECIALLY PREPPED. MSFT BLOG .... WIN8 boots too fast.... Microsoft's Building Windows 8 blog has been buzzing the last few days. Today, Redmond is talking about Windows 8 boot times. Specifically, the company is addressing the fact that the operating system can boot too quickly at times. According to Microsoft, Windows 8 can boot in as little as seven seconds. While most people herald this as good news, Microsoft understands that some of us actually want to interrupt that boot. However, though we might want to go mucking around in the BIOS or boot from an alternative device, Microsoft's Chris Clark says there is no longer enough time for detect keystrokes like F2 or F8. Clark goes on to say that while Microsoft isn't about to sacrifice its fast boot time to preserve these functions, there is a solution for those of us that live for F8 or that little "Press F2 for Setup" message.

Topic.Title: OMG, the 8 second boot time becomes the new In-Dell mantra

Message.Msg: Ah, the infamous mantra of the Microsoft-In-Dell consortium. If you are not happy with your current junk, then upgrade. Yeah, well after thirty years of uninterrupted junk, people aren't buying it any more. BTW, I was on the PCI SIG, USB committee and many other In-Dell puppet governments. It never will get better because In-Dell doesn't want it to. Once they build a perfect system, there will be no need to ever buy another one. Andy Grove said this himself during the Plug and Play launch in 1993. Look it up. Andy's words, not mine.

Message.Title: Dell XPS Ultrabook review - This guys loves it and loves the future of the PC
Message.Msg: First Impressions: Dell XPS 12 Windows 8 Convertible Ultrabook 10 comments, 7 called-out + Comment now One of the initial offerings in the new breed of Windows 8 devices is Dell’s XPS 12 (formerly the XPS Duo 12), a convertible ultrabook running the full version of Microsoft’s newly-released operating system. A review unit landed on my desk this weekend, and I wanted to offer up some first impressions as a prelude to the eventual review. A demonstration of the Dell XPS 12 Flip Hinge Design A demonstration of the Dell XPS 12 Flip Hinge Design This hybrid design is one that, in tandem with Microsoft’s Surface and the plethora of convertibles on the horizon, is poised to kill the traditional laptop. At first glance its flexible form factor is not only physical but also symbolic: Dell has given equal attention to the business professional and the savvy consumer. (More on that in the final review.) Microsoft Surface: First Impressions and Shattered Misconceptions Jason Evangelho Jason Evangelho Contributor The first thing that jumped out at me was the insane boot speed. From power on to ready to work in 11 seconds. Primary credit for this goes to Samsung’s 256GB solid-state drive, but also to the 8GB of RAM and an Intel Core i7-3517U. The XPS 12 is lightning fast, and it effortlessly handled importing roughly 50GB of music from a networked drive, syncing email and Skydrive folders, and browsing via Internet Explorer 10 with a dozen tabs open (simultaneously). I’ll run benchmarks in the near future, but this first impression didn’t disappoint. The XPS 12 display boasts a 1920 x 1080 resolution on a 12.5” screen, covered edge to edge with Corning Gorilla Glass. It emits as much brightness as Microsoft’s Surface (400 nit) and is stunning to behold. The aspect ratio results in an awesome movie-watching experience, and an equally enjoyable time flipping through magazines in portrait mode. Dell XPS 12 Flip Hinge A sexy but highly reflective screen The touchscreen was very accurate and responsive when using the onscreen keyboard or playing a few rounds of Radiant Defense. However, it did hitch when rotating between landscape and portrait position, taking just under 2 seconds to reorient itself. (I tested this with Word and a few other applications to be sure it wasn’t a software bottleneck. It may in fact be common across Windows 8, but more research is required). This isn’t a dealbreaker, but it is slower than the 3rd generation iPad or Asus Transformer Prime. Let’s briefly discuss the overall build quality. The chassis is made from machined aluminum, and the entire rim of the device (including the flip hinge) is composed of anodized aluminum. This combination lends the XPS 12 a wholly professional and sleek appearance. More importantly, every inch of this hardware looks and feels premium. Dell XPS 12 Metal Plate Something about this metal plate on the bottom of the unit screams quality The design decision I appreciate most is that the back of the display and bottom of the XPS 12 are both lined with a carbon fiber composite. It feels soft against your fingers and cool to the touch – important when it’s resting on your lap. One more bit of praise bordering on giddiness: The glass integrated trackpad feels downright luxurious. Seriously, head to your local tech retailer and touch the thing. Unfortunately there was one disappointing realization in examining the XPS 12 — no SD card slot, not even MicroSD. In all fairness, this could be a dealbreaker for some of you. During my first few hours with the XPS 12 I listened to a substantial amount of music. While ultrabooks and tablets definitely aren’t renowned for their superior audio quality, the maximum volume was surprisingly loud while remaining clear and without any distortion. This warrants a bit more exploration, but one thing’s certain: When this converts to tablet mode for media consumption, you won’t be straining to hear what you’re watching as with so many other products. Like my introductory time with the Surface, Dell’s XPS 12 will be a new experience for many consumers and those curious about Windows 8. My initial impression is nothing but delight. If this is the future of post-PC hardware, bring it on. I’ll reiterate that this isn’t a full review, but may serve as a tipping point if you’ve been curious about this particular Windows 8 convertible. Stay tuned for my final (and much deeper) analysis early in November.
